text: Damn. What a beer. Hazy and tart with citrus and grassiness. Nice caramel finish.

Shared 12.7 oz., 2015 bottle, with my portion served to a fest sampler showing a hazed, light gold/straw color, with modest, white froth that reduced quickly to a persistent ring, and some spots of lacing. The nose was bretty funk, soft malt/wheat, and a citrusy tartness & tanginess. The taste was similar, light to medium bodied, with some spritz to the effervescence, and continued funk that partnered with an earthy bitterness. Refreshing, on point Saison+ that cellared well and stayed fairly bright.

375 ml bottle pours a golden color with a nice white head. Aromas of yeast, peach, apple, light citrus. Light bodied, but complex, an excellent beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Brett, Biscuits, Mild Passuonfruit, Mild Pear...
Appearance: Amber/Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing...
Taste: Brett, Breast, Mild Tart Fruit...
Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying
Bottle - This is nice! Brett, but not too funky, warm biscuits, fruity, nice!!

Bottle from unknown place. Pours golden with a thugs head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Lovely citrus and Brett on the nose. Lovely blend of horse blanket and tartness on the tongue. Finished clean! Nice! Definitely a pantheon beer for the style.

It pours golden with a white head. It has plenty of Belgian lace on the side. Clarity is good. The aromas are highlighted by the brett with leather being the strongest aroma and barnhouse being in the background. It also has aromas of lemon, spicy notes, and some fruit. There are some subtle grainy notes as well that are not to distinct. The flavors are full of tartness. The flavors are highlighted by fruit and lemon with spicy pepper, leather. There is an initial bitterness that fades as the tart flavors take over. It has a light body towards the moderate side with a dry finish. There is also quite a bit of carbonation as well. Overall this is a highlight of the Brett with a complex mixture of hops and malts with the brett being dominant in the flavor and the other flavors provide a solid backbone.

375 ml bottle from Pearl Street Beverage in Burlington, VT, consumed at cellar temp from a Duvel glass. Pours a huge frothy snow-white head that diminishes with moderate haste above a lightly cloudy pale gold body...aroma at first comes off as skunky, but settles quickly into typical brett funkiness and tartness - a little bathroom, a little mildew, some fresh hay and some rotting, and a touch of sweet flowers on display after a few minutes in the glass....on the tongue its quite tart with a fairly strong acidity, and this plays out through the whole tasting, only moderating very slightly after at least 10 minutes more warming in the glass; its not quite so dry as a lambic but overall it is closer to a gueuze in character than any other non-lambic brett beer Ive had I think; not really all that much like a saison if you ask me and were I rating by style Id have to take off a lot of points there - this is a sour beer more than anything else and as such its a very good one, up to this great brewerys usual standards...it finishes in the mouth reasonably full with more than a little oaky-vinous quality; carbonation is strong but not at all overdone. Overall very good, bordering on excellent.

Bottle from The Ginger Man NY. Hazy amber color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, brett, white berries, peach, toast, spices, grass, a bit of butter and hops. Bitter finish with citrus, hops, peach, white berries, spices, hops and grass. Exquisite saison.

Peach and light crisp raspberry aroma. Hazy golden amber color with thin shimmering white head. Very crisp slightly tangy start with slight dry section then a quite mellow finish. Delish kiestro. Fo sho.

Smells like beautiful floral funk apricots tangerine with a straw sour. Pale hazy straw color light lasting layer of white head. Soft warm acidic fuzz grows a soft funk straw to accompany it to a nice dry lasting tart. Great body, flavors, warmth.

Bottle, caged and corked. Peach-colored and roughly opaque. The head is very finely packed and bright white, quite resilient. The brett-y wildness is fully evident in the first whiff. This drinks with a full-on pucker, overpowering the palate with some tropical fruit and a little bit of a saltine cracker. (#6386, 10/30/2016)

[8633-20160819] 375mL bottle. Yeasty fruity grains aroma. Hazy, pale orange yellow body with a medium-lasting creamy white head. Yeasty snappy grassy flavour. Medium body. Good. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4
(c/o mds, w/ him, jercraigs)

2016-08-19. Hazy yellow orange body with a very small head. 3+ Aroma is lightly fruity, musty with a hint of wood. Flavour is interesting, sort of citrusy, with mild bitterness throughout. What I thought might be grapefruit is probably passion fruit having read the label. Touches of wood. Average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Nice but did not quite live up to my hopes for it. 7/3-7/3/15-16 Bottle shared by mds.
Bottle. Opaque yellow pour with a fluffy white head. Inticing apricot bouquet. Whoa, thats tasty. Mild sour Aron fruits, brett, and oak notes dominate. Good body and mouthfeel.

375ml January 2016 bottle from Craft Beer Cabin, thanks Guillaume for buying. Aroma: big citrus nose mixed with some ripped green raisins giving this white wine aroma light acetic notes (vinegar), really far biscuit malt. App: cloudy golden with huge head slowly cussing to a small head, good lacing. Taste and palate: medium body, high carbonation, lots of lemon juice in mouth, finish is moderately acetic. Overall: when too cold I didnt enjoy much the mouthfeel. Combination of the big citrus acidity with the big carbonation made it a bit hard to drink. But once a tad warmer and the carbonation settled, I find it much much better. Another great beer from Allagash.

04.08.2016, 0,375l bottle shared @ BBGTC tasting:
Nice fizzy-creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly dry mineraly, yeast, flowers, dried fruits, minerals, light malts, citrus peel, hay, dried fruits, soda powder, grass. Taste is slightly dry mineraly, weeds, minerals, yeast, sour grass, flowers, sour berries, hay, oak, soda powder. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mineraly mouthfeel. Nice.

0.375l corked bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. This one has a cloudy, or perhaps more blurry golden colored body with a small islandy and kinda shattered white filmy head. Like the aroma. Bretty, gooseberries. Lots of Brett actually. Elderflower, some peach sweetness. Like it. Tastes really good. It has a almost growing carbonation level wrapped inside a nice oily texture. More peachy fruity elements. Its definitely up-bretted and quite on the tasty side. A hint of both apple and canned pear. A sourish hint. Lots and of flavor, and I really enjoyed this one. 04.08.2016

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a clear golden body with a small white head. Nose is pale malts, straw, honey, elderflowers and hints of straw, white sugar and faint bretty notes. Taste is gooseberries, citric notes, bretty stable notes, straw and hints of pale malts, pineapples and hay. Light body, medium to high carbonation. Nice and mellow brett saison with lots of floral tones. Very enjoyable.

Bottle, as pictured. Saw the label and decided to give it a try. Nice beer, tons of tartness from the Brett but not too funky or sour. I can definitely agree that it would be best fresh. Somewhat fruity, maybe like apricot or something like that.

9th June 2016Level 42 Bottle share. Thanks to Colin. Hazy paleish gold beer, thin pale cream colour head. Palate is light and dry, reasonable fine carbonation. Light sourness. Mild lemon segues in to a floral mid. Bitterish seltzer. Light dry finish. Its all right.

Bottle. Tart nose, with citrus, light stone fruit, and funk. Pale straw color. Mild but very pleasant tangy fruitiness, mid palate goes a bit sweeter, and bitterness perfectly complements that. Thin-medium body, gentle and pleasant on the tongue. Great stuff, with moderate funkiness and exceptional balance.
Bottle. Soft brett in the nose, grapefruit, apricot, subtle and refined. A touch of vinegar, passion fruit. Soft, lovely malts, great fruit, apricot and grapefruit. Zesty. Classy stuff.

A bretinomyces nose with a hint of fruit. Pours a hazy gold color with a small white head with nice lacing. Great taste of fruit, and a hint of Belgian yeast. Medium body with a hint a of fruit and yeast in the finish.

Poured from a bottle. Hazy yellow color, medium frothy white head. Medium sour fruit aroma. Medium body with a sweet allspice flavor and a medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared on Level 42, 09/06/2016. Many thanks to Colin for this one. A hazed, yellow straw coloured pour with a sticky thin white head. Aroma is sour funky horsey, lemon, bretty. Flavour is composed of tangy lemon, citrus, pithy, bretty funky, straw, funky, bretty. Palate is light and tangy, spritzy carbonation. Good.

Bottle at level 42, thanks to Fergus. It pours cloud yellow - gold with a thick white head. The aroma is fresh, bready, sour green apple, lemon sherbet and earth. The taste is crisp, tart, juicy, earth, wood, lemon - lime, sherbet, mild acidity and earth. Medium body and fine, foamy carbonation. Refreshing and quaffable. Rather nice.

38cl bottle shared at the Leightons Back tasting @42nd Level, CW. Many thanks to Colin for this one. It pours a lightly hazed straw color with a medium white head. Aroma is Brett and funky with tangy notes of lemon and straw. Taste is also citric tangy and lightly acidic with more notes of lemon and Brett. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, tasty

Bottle share at 42nd Floor as Allagash Century Ale, 8%. Vibrant lemon yellow, hazy, lightly sparkling, foamy white head. Aroma is lemon, musty, soap, bretty. Body is light, a bit frothy, soft carbonation. Taste is lemony, bretty, lime, light floral notes, touch of chalk, light soap. Pretty tasty.

Bottle split at Level 42, me picked this oop in CA, 09/06/16.
Hazed orange golden with a moderate off white head.
Nose is pissy melon, straw, funk, yeast esters, bitter orange, yuzu strokes, brett notes.
Taste comprises funky licks, nettle soup, tangy orange, straw, lemon rind, yeast light, pissy strokes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid saison work.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle shared in London - big thanks to Cloin. Pours unclear yellow-gold with a slender, foamy white head. Nice aroma with moderate farmhouse yeast expression, rindy lemon, hay stacks. Light sweet flavor with subtle acidity, mild bitter straw, more lemony notes. Light bodied with delicate carbonation. Nicely balanced finish with some lemon peel, light acidity, slight bitter hay, more farmy yeast. Great beer.
Golden colored, moderate head, good lace/retention. Aroma is barnyard action, brett, lighter fruit, touch of citrus, bread. Medium bodied, moderate brett presence - well balanced.
Tap. Cloudy night straw gold. Bretty, lemony, peach, and white gape must in the aroma. Flavor is less Brett heavy, lots of stone fruits, homegrown grapes, and dry hay finish. Lighter to medium body.
Incredibly good. Mostly tart with some fruity sweet to balance . Same for nose. Excellent body. serious sour beer.

In bottle (limit one per customer at Wegman's). Cloudy golden with a nice white head. Nice aroma of tart fruit. Taste of sour apricot, light citrus, exotic tropical fruit. Medium body. Tart, sour, takes a couple of sips to get used to it. Complex and interesting. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated 12.7 oz. brown bottle corked and caped poured into a tulip. Deep golden with big fluffy white head. Aroma is yeasty, medium/light body, low carbonation, and thick big-bubble lacing. Taste is slightly tart, yeasty, floral hops, some funk, and dry finish.

On tap at Beer Belly. Pours a clear gold with a medium sized white head. Soft acid on the nose, a touch of citrus, sweet fruit, soft musk. Medium bodied, soft musk, a touch of tart acid. Slow wood, dry yeast, musk, soft acid with some floral notes. Lovely.

Robe dorée, trouble, fine mousse blanche. Nez superbe sur des notes de mangue, de fruits de la passion, de citron vert sur un fond de levure. Bouche à lattaque acidulée, un très beau fruit, de la tension et une superbe finale à la fois longue et acidulée. Une superbe bière entre la saison et la wild ale. Jadore.

375ml->tulip. Slightly hazy golden orange with big frothy offwhite head. A: lots of tartness, brett, flora, slight spice. T: some tart, grains, brett, flora, yeast. Really nice. Dry finish. Great saison.

4oz pour at The Sovereign. Poured a golden yellow color with a nice fluffy head atop it. Funky notes, light acidic, touch of tropical funk. Delicious. Carbonation is on point, its tart, but not too puckering.

Sunshine yellow in color... Aroma of biscuits, grains, citrus, peppers, buttery chardonnay oak... Flavor is light pepper, spices, Brett funk, citrus, Chardonnay wine, lemon, grains... Very good 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cool nose of oranges pine apple coconut herbal notes Brett funk. Hazy golden yellow pour thin white head lace. Flavors of oranges some pineapple banana Brett funk mild tanginess a little bread mild herbal bitterness. Nice carbonation crisp lightly warming. Solid. Especially after that space station "saison" fuck.

375ml corked. Slightly hazed golden with somewhat flabby white head. Musty, blanket, lemon, hints of bubblegum and sawdust. Tart lemon, with some aspirin minerality, some herbal character in there as well. Finishes on the drier side.

Bottle at home. Pours lightly hazy gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is funky Brettanomyces, apricot and peach esters, straw and biscuit malt. Flavor is bright fruity esters, light earthy hops and bitterness, crisp straw malt, Brettanomyces and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle to glass. Pours a slightly hazy golden light orange color with a frothy off white head. Aroma is very pleasant, tart, citrusy, light funk, yeast. Flavor is crisp, light citrus and tart. Refreshing. Very nice.

Light geuze color, littler head and carbonation than expected. Milder aroma than expected, good brett is subtle. Airy like saison, but dont like the balance. Too much forward on front of tongue. Not enough lasting flavor. May work to age, but could also dry out more.
The perfect easy drinker complex saison, This has it all in very little balanced amounts. Apples, spices, leather, berries, light funk, bitterness, grassiess. Very charming.

$15/375ml. Bottle from shelf. Pours gold with a large head. Nice pop when I removed the cork. Aroma of citrus and funk. Taste is lightly bitter and dry. Flavors of lemon, cobwebs, foggy woods. Blair witch. Very similar to a certain HF saison. This is a great beer, although not in the upper echelon like their cuvée dindustrial.

Got this from a church giveaway, two towns over .. . murky gold .. foam from the sea .. . lots of brett goodness, light wood and hay .. . easy on the mouth, pretty good brett forward beer .. . . 108 degrees and the cat flips over!
Bottle thanks to Graeme. Pours a cloudy gold with medium frothy white head. The aroma is strong brett, funk, lemon zest. Medium mouth, funk, brett, lingering dry finish, very good.
Pours cloudy golden amber with a finger of white head. Aroma of bretta, citrus, apples, light honey. Taste is rich apple tart with a honey sweet finish. Light, crisp body with soft carbonation.

Pours sparkling gold into a tulip. Bright white head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Citrus and funk aromas. Dry with sweet caramel and brett upfront turning to fruity yeast and chardonnay before the lasting bitter earth and marshmallow finish. Very wine like.

Appearance: deep golden orange, hazy, with a finger of white head and some spotty lacing.  Aroma: titanic nose, full of citrus and tropical fruits, a big punch of earthy, funky, sharp brett, and an undertone of pie crust.  Taste: 	sharp and tart initially, smoothing off as it warms, full of bright, slightly tart pineapple, mango and peach, with some grapefruit; the brett is at first very strong, then mellows into a generous funk.  Finish: lingering yeasty funk, slightly peppery, with the tart fruit drying slowly. Notes: Fascinating. Brett and the fruity hops made for a real treat. Bottle for Beerthday 2015.

Bottle, 375ml. Shared in the koelship room at the source. It pours a lightly unclear pale golden body under a small off-white head. The aroma is on the funky side, with peaches and a generic tropical fruityness. Its lightly tart on the palate, full-bodied, smooth and with a nice carbonation level. Decent bitterness, some peppery yeast, funky fruityness and a faint malty touch in the flavor. Balanced bitter and fruity finish with some biscuity hints. Lovely. 150609

This beer is coming together nicely with a few extra months in the bottle since release. Much more complexity in the palate. Pours a medium golden color with a touch of yeast haze and two fingers plus of gaseous white foam. Layers of rustic malt, watercrackers, hints of stonefruit, spicy grass and a lemon barnyard funk draw out the finish with a touch of bitterness on the backend. Tasty.

Awesome stuff here. Hazy golden pour with white head. Aroma is stone fruit, pear, citrus, biscuit, and light funk. Taste is very slightly spicy black pepper and fruit with a touch of tartness on the finish. Subtle delicate and tasty.

Oak, farmhouse funk, lemon and crabapple nose. Hazy golden, thick head. Dry and tart, brett and lemon. Subtle grass finish. Medium body, easy carbonation, alcohol not the least bit evident. Standard well made brett sour, but with a reasonable hop note. Bright and delicious.

Bottle - 375mL corked and caged. Cloudy gold with a tall, fluffy white head. Aroma is funky yeast, earthy notes, overripe fruit and straw. Taste is big yeast, fruit, grains, doughy malt, sour fruit and straw. Body is medium and very effervescent with a prickly carbonation. Ends with more yeast, tart fruit, fruit juice, earthy notes, grains, biscuit and straw.
Bottle at tasting, pours golden haziness. Notes of peach, Brett, oak, lemons, and grain. Medium in body. Pretty good for Allagash.

375 mL bottle from Beer Run. Hazy yellow, large pillowy white head, lots of visible effervescent carbonation. Good head retention. Aroma of brett, pale bready malts, buttery notes, floral notes, stone fruit finish. The taste is brett, stone fruits, grassy herbal notes, pale malt, tart finish. Medium bodied, high carbonation, mild lingering tartness, well balanced. Very nice beer.

Bottle @ home. Hazed light orange colored beer with a white head. A ton of tropical fruits, particularly pineapple and mango. Some tangy lemon and lime zest, too. Maybe some unripe melon. Theres a really good citric acidity to the flavor. Big time melon, pineapple, and maybe passion fruit. Slight grassy and yeasty finish. Pretty nice.

[ Bottle ][ 375mL ][ Texas Liquor ][ $18 ][ Riedel Vinum XL Pinot Noir ][ 6.14.15 ]
>> Hazy gold color, minimal foam, high carbonation. Nose is candied pear, starfruit, cantaloupe, peach. Peach cobbler as it warms up. Taste is grisette or table beer- more subdued...Bubbly, yellow apple, sweet pear, no acid, mild sugar, slight wood. Soft and delicate, great quenching saison. Too bad the price makes it a "try it once" beer.

Une marre un peu lourde et fromagée qui libère aussitôt une quantité impressionnante de fruits pales juteux comme lananas, la mangue, le lichee et labricôt en moindre mesure. Une touche de brett adipeux ferme chaque gorgée avant quune sécheresse timide se manifeste sur le tard.

Bottle courtesy of Paul. Pours a light golden yellow with white lacing. Mouthfeel is soft, crisp, tart and bright with notes of fresh funky yeast, sour fruit, lemons, soft funk, clean grain and wheat. Nice.

Bottle 375ml @ Allagash Brewing Company, Portland, ME
Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, yeast, brett, pepper and some fruits. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long dry, yeasty, brett and fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft
Caged and corked bottle. Poured a hazy golden color with an averaged sized head. Citrus, some funky / brett, yeast, and spice.

Solid pop from c&c bottle leads to a golden yellow..light orange hue..all kinds of carbonation to start produces a frothy impressive 2 finger head..nose does have the passion fruit as stated on bottle with tropical fruit..lemon grass..bit of kiwi..wild notes from the brett are also noticeable with some funk..mouthfeel is quite quite good with lemony spice notes as what is typical of a saison but the brett raises the ante to produce a fruity..complex..funky bit of lemonheads..offering that seems like a hybrid of a saison and a wild ale...the 8 is hidden well..damn this is a tasty take on a saison..

On tap at Tasty. In a word, great. Allagash knows how to do a saison- plain and simple. Pours a hazy orange golden with a white head. Nice, mellow saison notes that are perfectly in balance with Brett funk. Appealing spice (pepper, light clove) notes with enough sour to keep in interesting. Light yeast notes. Drinks very clean and crisp. The Brett adds another level to a solid Saison- loved it.
Hazed gold pour, white head. loads of great funk,light sourness, some peppery notes. Hints of fruit, yeast...good drinker.
Bottle from Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours golden with an attractive off-white head and a yeasty fruit aroma. There is a fruit and toffee flavor with a dry tart finish. Lots of yeast presence.
Light gold, small white head. Light, yeasty aroma. Flavor of yeast, spice, grassy hops. A bit disappointing...
draft at Moor Pat, Williamsville NY. great funky fruit forward saison. golden pour, medium bodied, lots of tart fruit, funkiness, citrus notes. clean, crisp & funky. very nice
Bottle. Pours yellow gold white head. Nose/taste of lemongrass, peppercorn, lemon, citrus peel, brett and light funk - medium body.

500 cL cc botle from Whole Foods PM. Pours hazy golden with fizzy, white head. Nose is funky yeasty, hopcitrus, lactic tartness. Tastes funky, yeasty, with notes of hopcitrus, apricotty fruit, peach, mango, finishing tartness, more funk. Complex and delicious.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours golden wtih low white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is of perfume, vanilla, oak, bretts, caramel. Taste is of bretts, fruits, acidity, citrus, some bitterness. Palate: Light-medium body. Medium carbonation. Overall: Quite nice. Very interesting kinky saison yeast.

bootle. pleasant wheat malt backing with a bit of biscuit character. low to moderate sourness. yogurt with a touch of lemongrass. peteable pear fruit and a bit of earthy doughy forest fog. moderate carbonation, dryness. seems like half soured ale and half bretty belgiumed ale. all the individual pieces are kind of neat, but would perhaps like this to be split into two separate beers. drinkable.

Bottle shared by Minderbinder, huge thanks bro! Pours a clear golden and is topped by a small white rim that leaves low lacing. Nose is of fruits, dirty socks, brett funk, sulfur and oak. Taste is of fruits and white wine, lightly earthy. Recognizable as a saison but not a really good one to me. Body is medium and carbonation moderately high. Overall it was OK, a bit of a letdown knowing who it is coming from, though.

bottle shared by minderbinder, many thanks for this one bro! pours unclear light but bright golden with a nice white cap, good retention and lacing. pale crackery maltiness, crisp pils, light peppery wheat, subtle yet fragrant floral citrus, very nice fruity esters - orchard fruitiness-galore with a tropical touch; winey character - dusty white grapes and fruity bretts. bright to average carbonation, light body; gently tannic/astringent, tart and floral-citrusy finish. very very good stuff, although i prefer their regular tastefull saison.

The beer is a yellow, fairly pale with a touch of orange. The head is fairly fizzy and white. Little lacing and fades away quickly. The liquid is cloudy but I kicked a good amount of sediment. The aroma is tropical fruit with some lime and a background of dusty, earthy saison character. The beer has a sort of overripe fruit flavor, which is nice enough, but as it warms, some cheesiness comes out and the combination doesnt quite work for me. Theres also some simple pale malty sweetness knocking around. Mild funk. Id prefer a bit more saison flavor and a bit less malt. The taste is nice enough. Friendly saison yeastiness and fruity hops. Mild but definite bitterness. A little tang. It dries out some in the finish. Medium full feel. Some effervescence, fizz.

Pours a golden color with a white head. Fruit, spice, yeast, brett, funk and hop aroma. Pear, apple, peach, honey, spice, yeast, brett, funk and biscuit flavors. Medium light body and average carbonation. Fruit and funk finish.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle, thanks Aaron! Hazy golden pour with white head, aroma brought notes of nice funk earth, bread, some nice vanilla, some tropical fruit into a bit of yeast, slight grain into a bit of yeast. Taste was a mix of grain, bread, vanilla, nice oak, slight white fruit, peach, stone fruit, hints of grain, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter, slightly tart.
Nose is peppery, pineapple, peach. Flavor is same plus some lemon zest accents, wheaty/grainy. Finishes dry with lingering citrus. Ridiculously good

Bottle @ Steve_0 during my 10k tick fest. Thanks Lukaduke. Hazy golden orange appearance with a thin white head. Lemon, tangy tropical fruity, honey, funky nose. Juicy, pretty well carbonated. Lemon, honey wheat flavor. Pretty fine.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man! Pour is clear golden with a big white head and decent lacing. Funky, herbal, biscuit, grassy, white pepper, doughy, hay, and basil in the aroma. Taste is lemon, grassy, biscuit, tannic, white wine, some wood, pepper, herbs, and vanilla with a lightly tart finish. Light body with high carbonation. Pretty good and easily chuggable.

375 c&c from Capitol Beer in Sacramento, CA. Pours hazy gold with a transient, slight white head. Aroma is hard bread with lightly cooked stone fruit. Sour and/or brett notes. Med body. Spritely carbonation. Flavor is very lightly bready, bretty, and has a sour light stone fruit - like nectarine. Maybe apricot. Finishes towards a bit of bretty citrus. Quite smooth. Earthy, but not really horse blanket. Finishes dry and astringent. Quite nicely done.

Very very pretty pour. A bright, hazy, lemon-rind yellow in the glass with two fingers of sticky and lacing white head. Very very nice aroma with notes of fresh cut strawberries, lychee, tropical fruit, soft French bread, and grass. Tart and a little tannic at the front of the mouth with a grassy quality and notes of pineapple. Light bodied and dry with a bright citrusy note on the finish.

Bottle from Berts
Lightly hazy yellow straw with a decent sized white head. Big lemony earthy notes with a supporting funkiness to it. Crisp tart funk and refreshing. Very nice Saison.
Bottle. Light golden pour with white head. Fruity, full Brett and overall tart aromas. Funky, Brett, tart tones, touch of fruit flavor. After drink saison Brett this hold its own.

375ml bottle in a tulip. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of light Brett/tartness, some pale malts, hints of alcohol, and some light fruits. Flavor the same with an interesting blend. Average texture. A solid beer but not as cool as I was hoping itd be.

Bottle and Draft (previously). Pours with a slightly hazy pale hued body with a white head that fades a bit quickly. Aromas are of toast, brett, funk, bready, tropical fruit (hops and esters), passion fruit and ripe apple. Mildly goaty funk as well. Flavors are, very mildly tart, heavy pineapple, floral and citrusy hops, peach, ripe melon. Quite nice. Mildly mousey to TCA funk notes (not really at a level to distract). Crisp and very easy to drink. Slightly viscous mouthfeel that I occasionally get from beers heavy in oats or brewed with French Saison yeast. Very high (nice) carbonation.

Bottle, 04/24/2015. Pours a hazy orange color, thin white head fades rather quickly. Aroma is tangy citrus, lightly tart apricot, tropical notes, honeyed biscuit notes underneath with mild funk. Taste is light dusty malts with bright, slightly tart citrus and peppery bitterness blending with brett. Medium body, spritzy. Wow, nice stuff.

Bottle. Hazy yellow with fluffy off white head. This one is a little weird in a good way. Starts out as a tart saison with citrus fruit and grass, and as the finish kicks in it adds a very strong caramel kind of note, ending on toasted biscuit. The caramel becomes less prominent as the beer warms. Not at all what I was expecting but this was very interesting.

Bottle. Lemonade color. Rubber, oak, fruity yeast, dirty grass, melon, white wine. A little bitter on the finish. Pretty good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottle from Shoreline Beverage pours a hazy gold with some frothy, white head. Nose has a very nice mix of white grape, buttery oak, and lemon peel, some herbs, straw, a little wormwood, wood shavings, some kumquat, dusty couch. Flavor is lemon and lemon peel, straw, bouqet garni, buttery oak, wood shavings, a little agave, some white peppercorn, a little carpet, muscat grapes, some yellow squash. Spritzy finish.

375ML stored upright for 2 weeks @ fridge temp (35F) enjoyed 2 weeks in stemware a bit cold so I allowed it to warm. Very cloudy, hazy 1 finger dense creamy head. Smells like oak, peach, persimmon, peppercorn and wood. Taste is nice. mineral water mouthfeel, dense, has an efervescent quality, graham crackers, peppers, peaches and tree fruit. funky but on the lighter side.

375 ml and to be honest this traveled in a car before I opened it so the yeast was shook up so it is not clear at all. Bottled 5 February 2015. Aroma is citrus forward with a solid of funky yeast. 
The flavor is again citrus forward with lemons, limes, grain and mild band aid. The brett is taking over with a good balance of citrus. Not sure how this sat around this long before it hit distribution in NH but.... Anyone who lives in NH knows distribution here is not good. This brew is exactly as it should be and Im glad it sat around a tad.
Bottle shared by AirForceHops. Thanks, Chris. Pours pale yellow gold with a white head. Aroma is melon, citrus and oak. Flavor follows. Brett, citrus, oak. Nice.
375ml bottle pours a golden color with a bit of head. Nice Brett but the hops over power a little.

The Sampler, Brooklyn tap: pours pale gold with a white head. Aroma is brett, funk, straw, and mild fruit. Taste is sweet and tart. Finish is dry with a fruity tinge. Complex and interesting. Quite light. Good.
Bottle, thanks E-Dub, one of the best beers ive had in awhile, orange pour, white head, nose is citrus, taste is passionfruit, tart, amazing

Draft. Hazy golden yellow color, fluffy white head with good retention and solid lacing. Nice aroma of dusty attic corners, overripe lemons. Taste is fruity, peppery, dusty barnyard. Dry finish. Delicious.

375 ml bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Bottled 2/5/2015. Hazy golden yellow with 2.5 fingers of off-white head. Aromas of Brett, some funk, floral notes, herbs, lemon citrus. Tastes of citrus, floral notes, Brett and funk, lightly tart lemons. Medium body with a dry finish. Another nice saison from Allagash.

Bottle from Meditrina. Pale hazy yellow gold with flat white head and a little lace. Tropical fruity tart funky aroma with hints of bread grass and lemon. Topical fruity sweetness with some mild honey biscuit and lemon funk and wheat tang. Clean funky fresh finish. Medium light body, beautiful for abv. Lively carbo. Excellent. I was getting worried that I didnt appreciate sours anymore. I guess I just had the wrong sours.
UPDATED: APR 13, 2015 Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color with white head. Funky, tart, hay, barnyard aromas. Funky, wet blanket, citrus, hay flavors. Pretty damn nice.

Bottled 2/5/15, drunk 4/9/15Off-copper body (like that one?) is topped by a white head that is initially large but fully recedes to nothing. Clarity is high, leaving the plentiful sediment behind.Full-on brett nose pushes forth even from underneath the hop notes, which are delightfully herbal and citric (dry tangerines, meyer lemons) as touches of biscuity malts are lost in the shuffle. No alcohol or any flaws noted in the nose.Breezed through the aroma so I could get to the flavor which is more interesting. Not because the aroma isnt incredible; it is, but because Im very torn on how I feel about this beer, based on its flavor.Its deliciously brett-laden; lots of lime skins, hickory, light band aids, etc....and the malts are well attenuated but still leave structure behind, contributing a light, but ample body. The flavors are all very cohesive, nothing here dominates or comes off showy. So in that regard, whats not to love? A wonderfully understated, drinkable, graceful brett saison. Ah, but therein lies the problem. Is this a saison? I dont doubt they pitched saison yeast in to it, but it dosent come through at all. Perhaps its a mild-mannered saison yeast, perhaps its just covered up by the brett and hop notes. I dont know. It does come off a bit sterile for lack of a better term. I guess thats a complement to the production of the beer but I cant help being a bit disappointed by how clean and neat this beer is. I guess that just dosent say Saison to me. Brett golden ale? Definitely. Saison? Not so much. Does it matter? No, not really.

Bottle shared by Jayhawk73. Thanks Jeff.
Golden Orange body with a half inch of white head. Brett, funk, earth, basement. Great nose. Some gueuze lambic type qualities in both the nose and flavor. I surmise this would get even better given time in the cellar. Well water, earth, hints of citrus. Nice.

On tap @ Allagash.

Appearance: Slightly hazy glowing yellow-golden with a medium white head and heavy lacing. 

Aroma: So fresh! Beautiful lemony presence, brettanomyces, pils malt, crackery notes, cider-like features and fresh cereals. Beautiful!

Taste: Mild tartness. Bright lemony presence, brettanomyces, cider/apples notes, herbal presence, pils malt and crackery malt.

Palate: Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Clean. Lemony and herbal finish. 

Overall: Wonderful stuff. Really tasty and if feels so fresh which is really impressive for a beer brewed more than 2 years ago (even considering the dry-hop). Super easy drinking. Loved it.
Wonderfully done. Subtle florals and well integrated bretta. Pours golden with ok head and lacing. Light tangy finish. Very easy to drink. Wonderful.

En fût à la brasserie. Il y a des jours dans la vie quon ne regrette pas dêtre chrétien. Le jour de la visite de la brasserie Allagash en fut un. Une belle visite, une dégustation inégalée en bonne compagnie. La Century fut la clou de cette dégustation. Une robe blonde. Un nez légèrement sauvage avec des notes citronnées. Une bouche maîtrisé, les bretts ne sont pas agressant. Le vieillissement en acier inox laisse les levures faire leurs effets sans les notes doxydations ou tanniques du bois. Du grand art!

On tap at the brewery. Glowing pale gold pour with white head. Aroma is really nice, bright lemony brett notes, fresh grain, light cidery aroma. Taste is super fresh, bright acidity, tart, lemony, light grainy sweetness. Palate is light, super dry, nice carbonation. Great stuff.

Blonde embrouillée. Anneau de mousse et dentelle déroulée. Superbe nez de fruits tropicaux et raisins blancs mangés par les bons microbes sur un fonds pils de campagne et sur un blé sauvage. Sur les papilles, raisins blancs et pelure de pommes, bretts, autres fruits de terre inconnue et structure céréalière parfaite. Belle présence en bouche. Huileuse et pétillante. Finale sur des fruits attaqués par les levures.
Draft at the Surly Goat. Delicious fruity brett saison with a touch of hops. Fruit over funk, the tartness is tucked in but findable. I love brett saisons, this is a very good one!

Tap at Blind Tiger for saison Saturday. Pours greenish yellow with sudsy head. Nose of lemons and lactic sourness. Tastes of lemongrass, oranges, hay, lacto, and a jolly rancher aftertaste. Sweet and tart. Quite tasty.
